title: 104_hr2756
content:
The American Health Security Partnership Act of 1995 aims to address the lack of health insurance coverage for 40 million Americans by providing assistance to each state to ensure that every individual has health insurance equivalent to federal employees. The American Health Security Partnership Act of 1995 defines "State" as each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia. It provides payments to States with certified health insurance plans under title II to assist in carrying out approved plans. The Secretary of Health and Human Services determines the amount of payment for each fiscal year. The American Health Security Partnership Act of 1995 provides payments to States based on their population and revenue system, as determined by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 103. TOTAL AMOUNT AVAILABLE FOR PAYMENTS. The total amount available for payments to States for fiscal years 1998 to 2003 is specified. TITLE II--REQUIREMENTS FOR COMPREHENSIVE HEALTH PLANS SEC. 201. IMPLEMENTATION OF CERTIFIED HEALTH INSURANCE PLANS BY STATES. SEC. 201. Each State must submit a health insurance plan to the Secretary by July 1, 1999, and have it in operation by January 1, 2000. The Secretary will certify State plans that meet the requirements. SEC. 202 outlines the required provisions of the health insurance plan. Each State must have flexibility in developing its health insurance plan, which must cover all individuals regardless of employment status, income, or health condition. The plan must also include portability, guaranteed renewal, and benefits comparable to FEHBP. The health insurance plan must provide coverage comparable to FEHBP and offer home- and community-based care as an alternative to institutional care. Premiums must be community-rated, ensuring equivalent charges for all individuals within a community. The health insurance plan must offer community-rated premiums and ensure coverage comparable to FEHBP. State supplemental payments are provided to ensure coverage at reasonable rates, with a focus on quality of care and cost containment mechanisms. SEC. 203 amends ERISA to allow states to regulate self-insured plans that align with a state-certified health insurance plan. SEC. 204 requires Medicaid payments to only be made to certified plans. Section 1903 of the Social Security Act is amended to require states to have a certified health insurance plan in order to receive payments under this title. Waivers may be granted for non-compliance for up to 4 quarters. The Social Security Act is amended to require states to have a certified health insurance plan to receive payments. States may be granted waivers for non-compliance for up to 4 quarters or due to circumstances beyond their control. Time periods of non-compliance will not be counted for deadline purposes. SEC. 205. Increase in minimum community spouse resource allowance under Medicaid to $50,000 from $12,000. Effective date is for quarters starting on or after October 1, 1995. TITLE III - Financing Mechanisms: SEC. 301. Increase in top income tax rate applicable to corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the tax rate from 35 percent to 36 percent in various sections. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. SEC. 302 of the Social Security Act is amended to revise the Federal Medical Assistance Percentage under Medicaid. The applicable maximum percentage is changed to 83% for quarters before fiscal year 1998 and 60% for quarters during and after fiscal year 1998. SEC. 303 increases excise taxes on tobacco products. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase taxes on cigarettes and cigars. For cigarettes, the tax per thousand is raised to $49.50, and for cigars, it is raised to $38.62\1/2\ per thousand. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase taxes on cigarette papers, tubes, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco. The tax rates for these products are adjusted to higher amounts per thousand units. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase taxes on pipe tobacco to $13.17\1/2 per unit, effective for articles removed after December 31, 1996. TITLE IV--TAX DEDUCTIBILITY OF HEALTH INSURANCE

SEC. 401. TAX DEDUCTIBILITY OF HEALTH INSURANCE.

(a) In General.--Part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, "SEC. 220. HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS." This section addresses the tax deductibility of health insurance expenses. In general, individuals can deduct 80% (or 100% for self-employed individuals) of medical insurance expenses for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The deduction is limited by earned income, including wages and salaries. The deduction does not apply if the taxpayer is eligible for subsidized health insurance through an employer. The deduction for insurance expenses under subsection (a) does not apply if the taxpayer or their spouse participates in a subsidized health plan provided by an employer. Additionally, the deduction cannot be used to calculate the amount allowable for a medical deduction or for determining net earnings from self-employment. Conforming amendments are made to sections 162 and 62 of the Code. The deduction for health insurance costs is added to section 62 of the Code, and amendments are made to the table of sections in chapter 1. The deduction for health insurance costs is added to section 62 of the Code, with amendments to the table of sections in chapter 1. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
